reasoning: The critique targets the essay’s Section 2.2.1 “random walk” picture of moral reflection/divergence, proposing instead that shared physical/game-theoretic constraints create an attractor basin that pushes societies toward stable, cooperative moral equilibria. If successful, this would weaken one important pillar of the essay’s pessimism about widespread convergence (and thus somewhat support WAM-convergence), but it does not directly address the essay’s main/metaethical reasons for pessimism (Section 2.4: realism/antirealism, motivation to act on ‘the good de dicto’, and ‘accuracy’ rather than mere coordination), nor the separate blockers/lock-in considerations; hence only moderate centrality. The argument offers a plausible mechanism (selection for stable cooperation, avoiding self-destruction), but it is underdeveloped: it doesn’t show that these constraints yield convergence on anything like the essay’s required target (accurate and motivational convergence on what’s best overall), rather than convergence on thin coordination norms, power-stability norms, or merely instrumentally shared policies. It also overstates that the paper ‘incorrectly dismisses’ instrumental convergence—since the essay explicitly discusses instrumental agreement and why it may break down when optimization power increases. So the critique is partly correct and fairly clear, but only modestly weakens the attacked claims, yielding a low overall impact on the position.
title: Convergent instrumental pressures create moral attractor basins overlooked by the random walk model
